Award.AwardTitle: Amino Acid and Peptide Asssembly: Mechanisms and Structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Michael T. Bowers at the University of California at Santa Barbara are investigating the mechanism of peptide assembly. Peptide and protein assemblies can contribute to many devastating diseases such as Alzheimer's disease because of amyloid formation. This is an active area of research both for its fundamental importance and its potential impacts on health. Through the studies on model amino acids and peptides, factors that control larger peptide and protein assembly can be learned, which can help the development of new therapeutic agents. The project is well suited for the education of scientists at all levels, including those underrepresented in science. Outreach activities to high school students in the Ventura and Santa Barbara areas are also part of the funded project. A free website that allows the accurate and rapid calculation of cross sections of model structures is also supported by this grant.

Specifically, this grant is focused on the assembly of amino acids and small peptides. In these studies, Ion Mobility based Mass Spectrometry (IMS-MS) is used as the main tool. In collaboration with the group of Gert von Helden at the Fritz Haber Institute in Berlin, IMS-MS is coupled with the Fritz Haber free electron laser to do spectroscopy on size and shape selected oligomers of both amino acids and small peptides. The overarching goal is to understand the molecular mechanism of the amyloid cascade that is often observed for peptides and proteins in systems related to many devastating diseases. The amyloid hypothesis states that peptides natively fold and isotropically assemble until at a system dependent size they rearrange to beta sheet and rapidly add monomers to form fibrils. The group, in past NSF support periods, observed this process for specific peptide systems. The current project seeks to understand these observations and to develop an algorithm that can accurately predict the predilection of a peptide or protein to form amyloid knowing only the primary structure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Peptides and proteins are the most fundamental biomolecules in living things and are composed of strings of amino acids. The non covalent assembly of these species has both positive and negative effects on life. Among the negative effects is their involvement in many prominent diseases, termed amyloid diseases. These include Alzheimr's disease (AD), Type 2 Diabetes (T2D), amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and many others. There are as yet no cures for any of these diseases and very few useful therapeutics agents available. While these are complex diseases with numerous contributing factors, the major reason there are no cures is that the assembly of the underlying peptides or proteins is a dynamic process and non of the active agents can be isolated nor can their structural evolution be obtained. Examples of how we have overcome this difficulty using iom movbility based mass spectrometry (IMS_MS) and atomic force microscopy (AFM) are given below.

One of the issues involved with amyloid diseases is the mechanism involved with their toxicity. ONe possibility put forward by David Eisenberg at UCLA is that their are common structural entities involved with the various amyloid systems. We have collaborated with Eisenberg to try out this idea on several systems and have gone further in testing others on our own. It turns out that a structure called a cylindren appears to associated with toxicity in all of the aggregating peptides we have investigated. A cylindrin is and out of register, anti parallel assembly of six peptides that close to form a cylinder like object that might penetrat the cellular membrane potentially leading to cell death. in this grant cycle we have shown that core fragments of the agents responsible for Alzheimenr's disease and ALS form cylindrens as terminal oligomer species and these cylindren species are toxic. This work is ongoing to new systems to broaden the possibility that cylindrins are ubiquitous toxic agents for numerous amyloid diseases.

A second example has to do with the interaction of disease agents from separate amyloid diseases. Epedemiological studeis have indicated that AD and T2D are coupled. If you have T2D then you are twice as likely to contract AD. In this grant period we looked at several systems to try to understand this kind of report, both dealing with the IAPP p[eptide involved with T2D. The first showed that a crucial  prion fragment PrP (106-126) cataysed the conformational transition of IAPP from itsw benign helix/coil for to its aggregating beta hairpin form potentially accelerating T2D. A similar effect was used when we mixed the R3 portion of the Alzheimer's protein tau with IAPP. These are the first molecular reports on how these diseases might communicate and and amplify pathological effects.

Finally, 15 PhD students and postdocs, 6 of whom were women, participated in the NSF funded work this grant cycle. Educating these young scientists is just as important as the research done and discussed above. And in an ongoing effort we initiated several years ago, 30 PhD students and postdocs visited 8  area high scools and gave brief research reports and had visits with over 3000 students, about 50% minority. Questionaires indicate that the program is very successful in attracting new young minds to science that otherwise wouldn't have had the incentive or confidence to try it.
